body.div:
July 29, 1915. Dear Harriet: I am going to ask you a great favour. I have succeeded in selling a book of Richard’s to a little firm here in Boston, Brown, to wit, who wishes to bring it out as one of a series they are publishing. They expect to issue the volume in November, but the book contains a poem — which I believe you have accepted, but have not yet published — called “Images.” Will you be an angel and print it between now and November, so that I can conclude the sale of the volume with Brown? Richard is awfully poor, as you know, and I would be a great thing for him to have a volume printed, and he naturally will not wish a poem of his which he thinks highly, not to be printed in it. He simply sent me the manuscript of the book, telling me who owned what poems and asking me if I could get it accepted by an American publisher. That is why I am doing the business for him. I shall be awfully obliged to you if you will do this for me, and of course I can promise
you that the usual acknowledgement will appear. Richard writes me that he has asked you to write a series of articles on American poetry for “The Egoist.” I do hope you will do it, as far too little is known about American work on the other side of the ocean. To my mind, “The New Republic” gets duller and duller. Perhaps that might be paraphrased into more and more political and less and less anything else. They have just accepted Fletcher’s “Clipper Ships;” but if they keep it as long as they have two poems of mine which have not yet appeared, it won’t do him much good, poor boy! By the way, “The Century” has just accepted a polyphonic poem of mine. It amuses me to think of anything so radical in so conservative a stronghold. Yes, Harriet, there is no doubt about it: you have had an immense effect upon the other magazines in this country, let alone the effect you have had upon the writers themselves. I am laying all this up to hurl at the head of the public in my article on you. I hope you are not as hot as I am. Thank Goodness, I am going to the country this week.
I have been kept here by Mrs. Russell not being very well. But now she is going West, and I am going to Dublin. My address there is simply: Dublin, New Hampshire. Affectionately yours,
